DISIA Name: Surbiton District Centre Inset Area
CONARA Name: Surbiton Town Centre Conservation Area
AIRCZ Type:: Gatwick Airport Wind Turbine Consultation Zone:Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Gatwick Airport Limited, 7th Floor Destinations Place, London Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH06 0NP

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

application_type_full: Full planning & demolition in a conservation area
description: Erection of four storey residential building in courtyard to provide 7 no. (4 x one-bedroom and 3 x two-bedroom) self-contained flats, cycle store (with new amenity deck above), infill extension to existing entrance courtyard with three storey extension comprising ground floor entrance lobby and 1 no. (one-bedroom) maisonette and two roof extensions to form 1 no. self-contained studio flat in St James Court and extension to existing unit in Claremont Court
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

Samples for all facing materials, railings and staircase furniture shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to above ground works. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples and completed prior to occupation.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)  and DM12 (Development in Conservation Areas and Affecting Heritage Assets) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works the following details shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, implemented prior to occupation and thereafter permanently retained. (a)  waste and recycling bin storage (including their manufacturer's specification, dimensions, colour and texture and capacity.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The hard surfaces hereby approved shall be made of porous materials and retained thereafter or provision shall be made and retained thereafter to direct run-off water from the hard surface to a permeable or porous area or surface within the curtilage of the property.Reason: To reduce the risk of flooding and pollution and increase the level of sustainability of the development and to comply with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason:  In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduce its lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance with Policies D4 and SI 1 of the London Plan (2021) Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works and with specific regard to the proposed courtyard development, details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.  The system shall be implemented prior to occupation and thereafter managed and maintained in accordance with the approved details.  Those details shall include a timetable for its implementation, and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.Reason: To prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policies D4 and SI 13 of the London Plan (2021), Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The windows related to the courtyard development shall be obscured as per the siting and design detailed on the following drawings: - 2531-RDJWL-01-ZZ-DR-A-0030 Rev C04- 2531-RDJWL-01-ZZ-DR-A-0031 Rev C04  - 2531-RDJWL-01-01-DR-A-0025 Rev C04- 2531-RDJWL-01-01-DR-A-0026 Rev C04- 2531-RDJWL-01-01-DR-A-0027 Rev C04- 2531-RDJWL-01-01-DR-A-0028 Rev C04  to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and must be replaced in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the adjoining premises from overlooking and loss of privacy, in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021).

Prior to occupation details of secure cycle parking facilities (including style and manufacturers specification) for the occupants of, and visitors to, the development hereby approved have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy T5 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with the following details which shall have previously been submitted to in the form of a Construction Management Plan and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of work:  (a) Statement on how the proposed development will be built, with method statements to outline how major elements of the works would be undertaken;(b) Proposals for loading/unloading materials, site storage etc;(c) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;(d) Deliveries/collections to and from the site should use a route that is agreed with NRSWA team. The agreed route should be signed accordingly.   (e) Protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;(f) Protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; and(g) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site, and whether a banksman will be provided;(h) Temporary site access;(i) Signing system for works traffic; (j) Site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads.(k) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site.  (l) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;(m) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;(n) Location of all ancillary site buildings;(o) Means of enclosure of the site; and(p) Wheel washing equipment.  (q) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policies D4 and T4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the Arboricultural and Planning Integration Report dated 29 July 2019 in relation to the retention and protection of the street tree on St James' Road.   Reason:  In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with Dwg No. 2531-RDJWL-XX-XX-DR-A-0051 Rev C1 - Landscape Layout.  Any planting, trees or shrubs which within a period of five years from the completion of the development die, are removed, or become seriously damaged or diseased shall be replaced in the next planting season with others of similar size and species. Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policies D4 and G7 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation details of the proposed species related to the living roofs and their associated irrigation systems and maintenance shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.  The approved works shall be carried out in the first planting season following the completion of the development.  Any planting which within a period of five years from the completion of the development die, are removed, or become seriously damaged or diseased shall be replaced in the next planting season with others of similar size and species.  All living roofs shall be permanently retained for that purpose only and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To ensure that these works are properly implemented and maintained and in the interest of visual amenity in accordance with Policies D4 and G7 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts, external lighting or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans additional detailed drawings at Scale 1:5/1:10 of the depth of reveals and projecting  bays, showing the relationship between the window frames and the elevations shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to above ground works.Reason:  In order that the special architectural and historic interest of the surrounding heritage assets are safeguarded in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy CS8 (Character, Heritage and Design) and Policy DM 12 (Development in Conservation Areas and Affecting Heritage Assets) of the LDF Core Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans additional detailed drawings at Scale 1:5/1:10 of the infill development showing the junctions and relationship between the adjacent structures and roof forms shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to above ground works.Reason: In order that the special architectural and historic interest of the surrounding heritage assets are safeguarded in accordance with Policies D4 and HC1 of the London Plan (2021), Policy CS8 (Character, Heritage and Design) and Policy DM 12 (Development in Conservation Areas and Affecting Heritage Assets) of the LDF Core Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with Dwg No. 2531-RDJWL-XX-XX-DR-A-0051 Rev C1 - Landscape Layout and the Konic lighting specification and information documents  in relation to the proposed external lighting. Reason:  In the interests of visual amenity and to safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012

Notwithstanding the details of privacy screens shown on Drawing Ref: 2531-RDJWL-01-03-DR-A-0028, Rev C04, details of privacy screens to be installed on the north, west and southern elevations of the balcony for the approved third floor 1 bed 1 person flat shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for approval in writing prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved. The proposed privacy screens shall be installed prior to the occupation of the proposed development and thereafter retained in perpetuity in accordance with the approved details unless otherwise first agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To safeguard the privacy of neighbouring properties and in order not to prejudice the development potential of neighbouring sites, in accordance with Policy D4 of the London Plan (2021), Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).
The submitted drawings are not labelled as existing or approved or proposed. Please amend the drawings with correct labelling as existing or proposed or approved.

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Non Material Amendment to planning permission 24/01488/FUL (Application under Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 to carry out development without compliance with Condition 1 (Approved Plans) and Condition 14 (Carbon Reduction) of planning permission 22/01273/KPSID(Demolition of existing buildings and associated structures and the erection of two storey building to provide new mental health floorspace together with ancillary and associated development including new and enhanced pedestrian routes /spaces and access, vehicular access, roads and car parking, servicing facilities, landscaping, infrastructure and other associated works) to allow for various design alterations to the approved Scheme.) to amend faÃ§ade and addition of 3nos ETFE roof, bifold doors at restaurant and change to LV switch room doors'.

We received only two elevations, we require all four elevations or sections.Please provide all four Existing and Proposed Elevations/Sections at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work
Please submit 'Fire Statement/Plan'. It is validation requirement.
Please submit 'Time Stamp Photo', it is validation requirement.
Please submit Cil Form.

Please revise the validation check list with updated information. Please check the new local list in our website before filling the validation checklist.The new local list and validation checklists can be obtained via the council's website- https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications.
Please submit 'Existing and Proposed Street Scene'.

The proposed site is categorised as a flat and the 'Ownership Certificate A' has been signed, please confirm the 'Ownership Certificate A' is correct, otherwise please amend the whole application form with correct 'Ownership Certificate'.
The proposal includes affordable housing units, therefore please submit 'Affordable Housing Statement'.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling.ProposalAlterations to existing ground floor rear extension with raising height of flat roof level. Erection of piggyback roof extension with rear juliet balcony and installation of 6nos side rooflighs. Raising roof height.Consultation6 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed piggyback extension resulting in a raised right height is compliant with Policy Guidance 40 of the Residential Design SPD as it has been set back from the front elevation by at lease 4m and the does not increase the height by more than 1.3m. The alterations to the roof of the single storey rear extension would not be visable within the streetscene. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  With regards to the piggyback roof extension, as this would not extend beyond the original rear elevation, officers have not identified any harm with regards to further loss of light. The proposed rooflight should be obscured glazing in order to mitigate light pollution and provided an element of privacy from overlooking. This would be secured by condition should permission be granted. In relation to the proposed roof height increase to the existing rear single storey extension, due to the limited height increase officers have not identified any further harm. Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy however it does not address all points under policy D12(A) fully. Officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Inspection: Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment: The works proposed are acceptable and will not have an adverse effect on the trees or reduce their amenity value. Recommendation: No objections.
For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Erection of a single storey rear extension. Roof extension with rear dormer and installation of 2nos front rooflights''.

Application SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling. The site is not subject to heritage or tree constraints and is not located within Fluvial Flood Zones 2 or 3.ProposalDemolition of an existing rear conservatory and side garage, erection of two storey side, single storey rear and front porch extension. Hip to gable roof extension with rear dormer and installation of 4nos front and 1no rear rooflights.Consultation6 neighbours were notified of the proposals. In response, no comments have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The single storey rear and front extensions are considered to be acceptable. The change of roof from hip to gable is not objectionable in principle, however, it is noted that the proposals conflict with Policy Guidance (PG) 36 of the  the Residential Design SPD in that: the storey side extension is only set-down from the newly raised ridge height by only c. 0.3m (a minimum of 0.5m is required), is only set in from the site boundary by c. 0.9m (a minimum of 1m is required) and is set back from the front elevation by only c. 0.82m  (a minimum of 1m is required). The proposed dormer conflicts with PG39 and would appear to be permitted development.The insufficient set-down from the raised roof ridge, insufficient set-in from the boundary and insufficient set-back from the front elevation results in an overly bulky form of development which detracts from the relatively open character of the area. Were No. 62 to extend in a similar way this would exacerbate the identified impacts and result in a terracing effect.For the reasons set out above, it is considered that the proposed development would be overly bulky and incongruous within the street scene and would harm the spacious character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  Having regard to neighbouring planning permissions at Nos. 58 and 62 Chiltern Drive, Officers are satisfied that there would be no unacceptable adverse impact on the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy, subject to the first floor side facing windows being conditioned as non-opening and obscure glazed.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy but it does not fully address the requirements of Policy D12(A). However, were Officers minded to grant planning permission a revised and robust Fire Safety Strategy could have been secured by planning condition.  ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in conflict with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Condition 10B (sustainable drainage scheme) of planning permission 22/03827/FUL states:B) No building hereby permitted shall be occupied until evidence (photographs and installation contracts) is submitted to demonstrate that the sustainable drainage scheme for the site has been completed in accordance with the submitted details. The sustainable drainage scheme shall be managed and maintained thereafter in accordance with the agreed management and maintenance plan for all of the proposed drainage components.Reason: To prevent the risk of flooding to and from the site in accordance with Policy SI13 of the London Plan 2021, the Sustainable Design and Construction SPG 2014, the Non-Statutory Technical Standards for Sustainable Drainage Systems 2015 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Officer Comment: The council's Local Lead Flood Authority has assessed the submitted details and has raised concerns in regard to the submitted details for the discharge of Condition 10B (sustainable drainage scheme). The applicant is advised to provide amended and/or additional details using the Drainage officers' comments below.The applicant has submitted a drainage layout that shows the approved drainage scheme. Submitted drainage layout drawing shows that two attenuation tanks of storages (97.81 m3 and 15.2 m3), a hydrobrake, and a rainwater harvesting system (water butt) is proposed to contribute to the sustainable drainage system. For the discharge of this condition, the applicant has submitted a site inspection report and drainage photographs showing the installation of the proposed attenuation tanks. However, photographs of proposed water butts and hydrobrake devices have not been provided. Also, the installation contracts have not been provided. This is required to ensure that the right amount of storage has been provided as approved.Therefore, the LLFA does not recommend the discharge of this condition as more information is required. The applicant should provide installation contracts to confirm what amount of storage was installed. Also, photographs of hydrobrake and all approved SuDS (including water butts) should be provided.

Inspection: Site inspection carried out as a desktop exercise with information provided by the applicant as supporting material to application.Assessment: The works proposed are acceptable and will not have an adverse effect on the tree or reduce its amenity value. Recommendation: No objections.

We received two sets of proposed plans, elevations and other drawings, we require only one set of proposed drawing, If one set of drawing is approved drawing from previous planning permission, please amend the drawings with correct labelling as approved or proposed.

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Non Material Amendment to planning permission 21/01951/FUL (Demolition of existing offices and erection of 5 storey registered care home for the elderly (Use Class C2) including the provision of parking, landscaping, revisions to access and all other associated works including parking provision, cycle parking and refuse/recycling facilities) to amend substation outbuilding, landscaping, screen on roof plan and brick details on elevation'.

The fee required for your planning pre-application advice is Â£1,500.  Payment can be made online via the Kingston council website, or via our Contact Centre on 020 8547 5002,

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single storey rear extensionConsultation5 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: With regards to neighbouring amenity the principal properties to consider are No.5 and No.9  Wyndham Road. The applicant has demonstrated the proposed rear extension would comply with BRE guidance in relation to the 45 degree rule and loss of daylight sunlight. Officers are satisfied that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Conditions 24 (Solar Panel Details) of planning permission 22/01923/FUL which states:Prior to the commencement of any above ground works (excluding demolition) and notwithstanding the requirements of Condition 23 above (Sustainability & Energy Statement), details of any solar panels to be installed on the roofs of the buildings hereby approved shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for approval in writing. The solar panels shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the approved details.The required details shall include elevation drawings, technical specifications and robust justification to demonstrate that the solar panels have been sited so as to minimise the impact on character and appearance of the area.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policies DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) and DM12 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.Officer comment: Whilst officers acknowledge that the applicant has provided technical specifications, the applicant has failed to provide scaled elevations which were requested in the condition, to ensure that the solar panels would not be visible in the streetscene. The parapet wall has a height of approximately 700mm and considering the solar panels would be mounted, the applicant must demonstrate the angle and height of the proposed panels on  scaled drawings.

The details submitted for Conditions 27 (Fire Safety Statement) of permission 22/01923/FUL have been assessed and are considered acceptable. However, as these conditions have been submitted under a single cover and the submissions for Condition 24 are insufficient, all conditions in this application can not be discharged and are refused.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 22 (Biodiversity Enhancement) of planning permission 21/01304/OUT  which states:The development to which this permission relates shall not be occupied until a scheme to enhance the nature conservation interest of the site has been submitted to and agreed in writing by the local planning authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented in full prior to beneficial occupation of the development. Reason: To safeguard the biodiversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with Policy G6 of the London Plan (2021) and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Application Site: The application relates to a two-storey detached property located to the west of Walpole Road and south of Glenbuck Road. The site is surrounded by predominantly detached residential properties with long gardens. The south-west railway line is located 130m to the north-west of the site. The site is not located within a conservation area nor is it, or located nearby to, a statutory listed building and non-designated heritage asset. The site is located within the Walpole Road Local Area of Special Character (LASC). The site has 3 trees at the Glenbuck Road frontage of the site are protected by Tree Protection Orders (TPO). Both road frontages are unclassified local roads. The site has a PTAL rating of 4 on a scale of 0-6b with 6b being the most accessible, meaning it has moderate public transport accessibility. The closest bus stop is Mountcombe Close, located 170m away, a 3-minute walk. The closest rail station is Surbiton, which is located 320m away, also a 4-minute walk. The site is within a controlled parking zone (CPZ). Proposal: The proposal is for the subdivision of existing property into 1 x one-bedroom flat and 1 x 6-bedroom dwellinghouse. Relevant History: 00/07107/FUL: Erection of single storey side and rear extension. Granted 31.05.2000. Consultation: A total of 33 neighbouring properties were consulted and no representations were received. Consultees: Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer: no objection. Planning Considerations: The key areas of assessment are:- Principle of Development - Character, Design and Impact on Heritage Assets- Housing Mix- Standard of Accommodation - Impact on Residential Amenity- Highways and Transportation- Fire SafetyPrinciple of Development: The Policy GG2 of the London Plan (2021) (LP) and Paragraph 125 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2024) (NPPF) promote the redevelopment of underutilised land for the delivery of housing. Policy CS10 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012) (CS) sets out the Borough's housing targets as defined by the LP. LP Policy H1 sets ten-year targets for net housing completions that each local planning authority should plan for. Table 4.1 sets out the 10-year targets for net housing completions in each London Borough from 2019/20 - 2028/29). The requirement for Kingston is to deliver 9,640 homes in this 10 years period which would equate to 964 net completions per annum.The Council cannot demonstrate a 5-year supply of housing land as required by the NPPF therefore, paragraph 11 of the NPPF indicates that planning permission should be granted unless (i) the application of policies in this Framework that protect areas or assets of particular importance provides a clear reason for refusing the development proposed; or (ii) any adverse impacts of doing so significantly and demonstrably outweigh the benefits, when assessed against policies in this Framework taken as a whole. In other words, the tilted balance weighs a development's adverse impacts against its benefits, not on a level playing field, but tilted towards granting permission. These considerations should be given considerable weight in the assessment of any forthcoming planning application. The proposal seeks to convert an existing 7-bedroom dwellinghouse into a 6-bedroom dwelling and 1-bedroom flat. There would be no loss of a family-sized dwelling in line with CS Policy DM14 and the creation of a separate flat would make a small but positive contribution to the borough's housing supply targets. This is afforded significant weight, especially in this sustainable location. Support for the principle of development is subject to compliance with Development Plan policies. Housing Mix:The NPPF at para 63 directs that the size, type and tenure of housing needed for different groups in the community should be assessed and reflected in planning policies. CS Policy DM13 states new residential development is expected to incorporate a mix of unit sizes and types, and provide a minimum of 30% of units as 3 or more bedroom units, unless it can be robustly demonstrated that this would be unsuitable or unviable.The proposal would reduce the existing house from 7-bedrooms to 6-bedrooms and create a 1-bedroom flat on the ground floor.  This is supported as the family-sized home would be retained in compliance with CS Policy DM13. Officers note the proposed plans state the dwellinghouse would be a small (6 persons) House in Multiple Occupation (HMO) however, this has not been included in the description of development on the Application Form. Any HMO established within the property would not benefit from planning permission. It is noted any future conversion of the subject approved property to a small HMO would not benefit from permitted development rights given it would involve two Class C3 dwellinghouses to a Class C4 HMO. Character, Design and Impact on Heritage Assets: Para 131 of the NPPF states the creation of high-quality, beautiful and sustainable buildings and places is fundamental to what the planning and development process should achieve.Paragraphs 213 to 221 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. LP Policy HC1 and CS Policies CS8 and DM12 echo these requirements.LP Policy D3 states that development should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions. CS Policy CS8 and DM10 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.No external alterations are proposed to the existing property. The only modifications would be internal floor layout to create a separate one-bedroom flat on the ground floor. Officers confirm there would be no adverse impacts on the character and appearance of the host property or broader LASC. This is given neutral weight in the assessment of the scheme. Standard of Accommodation: NPPF para 135 sets an expectation that new development will be designed to create places that amongst other things have a 'high standard' of amenity for existing and future users.LP Policy D6 sets out the standards for new housing within London, in terms of overall GIA, built-in storage space, bedroom sizes and ceiling heights. Housing development should be of high quality design and provide adequately-sized rooms, with comfortable and functional layouts which are fit for purpose and meet the needs of Londoners without differentiating between tenures. CS Policy DM13 states that the Council will expect proposals for new residential development to demonstrate that the scheme has been designed to provide adequate internal space appropriate to the intended number of occupants. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy requires developments to ensure adequate private and/or communal amenity space.The new flat would be 39sqm and the dwellinghouse would be reduced to 226sqm. The proposal would achieve the minimum internal space standards resulting in a functional and comfortable layout for future occupants in compliance with LP Policy D6.The new flat would be dual aspect and each habitable room would be serviced by at least one window for suitable ventilation, outlook and access to natural light. There would be no change in the ceiling height of the property which achieves a minimum 2.5m floor-to-ceiling height for at least 75% of the GIA, in compliance with LP Policy D6. Officers consider future occupants would be provided with a suitable level of  daylight penetration, ventilation and cooling and a sense of space. The existing property has a 377sqm rear garden which is proposed to be split for the benefit of the new flat and dwellinghouse, in compliance with CS Policy DM10 and Policy Guidance 13 and 14 of the Residential Design SPD. Officers would secure details of the proposed boundary treatments separating the rear garden via condition. The new flat would be accessible from the rear of the property via a side gate. The dwellinghouse would continue to be accessible from the front of the property. The proposal would meet at least Building Regulation M4(2) 'accessible and adaptable dwellings' in terms of step-free access, in compliance with LP Policy D7.In summary, the proposed unit and dwellinghouse would achieve an acceptable standard of accommodation for future occupants in compliance with LP Policy D6 and CS Policy DM10. Impact on Residential Amenity:NPPF para 135 sets an expectation that new development will be designed to create places that amongst other things have a 'high standard' of amenity for existing and future users. This is reflected in LP Policy D3. CS Policy DM10 is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposal involves no external alterations to the property, including no new windows or openings. As such, there would be no impacts on neighbouring amenity in terms of overbearing enclosure and loss of privacy. There would also be no noticeable difference in coming and goings to the property given it would be retained for residential purposes. The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of impacts on neighbouring residential amenity. Highways and Transportation: NPPF para 116 states development should only be prevented or refused on highways grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or the residual cumulative impacts on the road network, following mitigation, would be severe. CS Policy DM10 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. The existing property has parking space for 2-3 cars on the driveway. The existing car parking and access arrangement is not proposed to be altered as part of the proposal. The number of car parks exceeds the maximum standards under LP Table 10.3 (maximum of 0.75 car parks within an Outer London PTAL 4 location) however, given it is the same as the existing arrangement, the Council's Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer considers it to be acceptable. A Unilateral Agreement has been secured to restrict residents from securing parking permits within the CPZ. The applicant has stated that cycle storage would be provided within an existing outbuilding in the rear garden however, no details have been submitted. The cycle storage will need to accommodate a minimum of 3 cycle parking spaces for both the 1-bedroom flat and 6-bedroom property to comply with LP Policy T5. Details of the cycle storage would be secured by condition to ensure it is weatherproof, secure and accessible in line with the London Cycle Design Standards. No details of the proposed waste storage arrangement have been provided. Bins are currently located at the front of the property adjacent to the storage. Details of the waste storage would be secured by condition to ensure they comply with the required storage capacity standards under the Residential Design Guide SPD and the storage area is secure, weatherproof and accessible in line with CS Policy CS9. Overall, Council's Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has not objected to the proposal. The proposal would not adversely impact the local road network and would provide sufficient cycle and refuse storage facilities, subject to final details being secured by condition. This carries neutral weight in the assessment of the application. Trees and Landscaping: NPPF at para 136 states trees make an important contribution to the character and quality of urban environments, and can also help mitigate and adapt to climate change. LP Policy G7 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. CS Policy DM10 sets out that the Council expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.An Arboricultural Method Statement, Impact Assessment and Tree Protection Plan has been submitted. No trees would be impacted by the proposed development. The report recommends tree protection fencing be installed around the perimeter of the root protection area to protect the trees from any materials or machinery that may be brought on site. The tree protection methods in the report would be secured by condition to ensure compliance. The proposal is acceptable in terms of impacts on trees, subject to securing tree protection methods via condition. This is a neutral matter in the assessment of the scheme. Fire Safety:LP Policy D12 requires all developments to achieve the highest standards of fire safety. A Fire Strategy has been submitted that demonstrates the proposal would provide suitable means of evacuation and fire safety standards, in terms of materials and fire detection measures, in accordance with LP Policy D12. The Fire Statement would be secured by condition to ensure compliance. Conclusion and Planning Balance:This application has been considered in the light of policies set out in the development plan and other material considerations. The proposal would provide an additional flat whilst retaining the family-sized home which would make a favourable contribution to the borough's housing supply and comply with CS Policy DM13 which would carry position weight in favour of the application. The proposal exceeds the maximum residential car parking standards under LP Policy T6.1 however, given it replicates the existing situation this is afforded limited weight in the planning balance. Cycle and waste storage, tree protection and protection of neighbouring residential privacy are all neutral matters which would be managed by condition. Officers have taken into account the Housing Delivery Test tilted presumption in favour of development as set out in para 11 of the NPPF whilst considering the conflicts with the Development Scheme. The proposed development is considered to be compliant with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan. Officers recommend planning permission be granted.

You are reminded this planning permission does not approve the use of the property as a small Class C4 House in Multiple Occupation (HMO). If the property is to be converted to a HMO, you would need to apply for full planning permission.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Condition 89 (Ground Level Details) of planning permission 20/02942/FUL states:Prior to any above ground works (excluding demolition) details shall be submitted to and approved by the local planning authority of the ground level of each plot to demonstrate adequate access for all users. The development shall be implemented in accordance with the approved details. Reason: In order to provide adequate access for persons with disabilities or push chairs in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.Officer response: The submitted information is considered to be sufficient. The proposed ground levels would provide adequate access for persons with disabilities or push chairs across the Plot C. As such, the details submitted in relation to Condition  89 (Ground Level Details) for Plot C, Phase 1 only are hereby approved.The approved details relate only to the proposed ground levels, any other information shown on the drawings would require a separate application.

Reasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans/documents submitted for the purposes of this application are consistent with the parent planning permission reference 20/02942/FUL, however, any inconsistencies would be resolved in favour of the parent permission. An Application for Approval of Details Reserved by Condition should not be used to evolve or modify the scheme in a way that is substantially different from that set out in the application.
The approved details relate only to the proposed ground levels, any other information shown on the drawings would require a separate application.
